conclusion: Understand how the position and size of shadows change when the light source moves downward.
Object A is a small, light-colored object (possibly a figurine).
Object B is a black object with a floral pattern.
Object C is a red object (possibly a cake or a similar item).
Object D is a roll of tape.
Shadow A is cast by Object A.
Shadow B is cast by Object B.
Shadow C is cast by Object C.
Shadow D is cast by Object D.
When the light source moves downward, the angle at which the light hits the objects will change.
As the light source moves downward, shadows will generally become longer and more spread out.
Shadow A will move further away from Object A and become longer.
Shadow B will move further away from Object B and become longer.
Shadow C will move further away from Object C and become longer.
Shadow D will move further away from Object D and become longer.
Final answer: Shadows A, B, C, and D will all become longer and move further away from their respective objects.
